poured over so almond cubes float. Garnish with slivered almonds
strawberries or canned fruit such as mandarin orange sections

Baker's Craft Dough;4 c Unsifted flour;1 c Salt;1 1/2 c Water;1 tb Powdered Alum (preservative);1 tb Cooking oil (easier to work);;1/4 ts Food color;1/4 ts Clove or peppermint oil;Acrylic paints;Spray acrylic fixative;Clear shellac;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Mix together flour

will knead as you work into smaller pieces and the dough will stay
soft.
Store dough in the refrigerator until ready to use. It will remain in
good condition for up to 4 weeks. Let it warm to room temperature
before using.
To Use: Generously flour the work surface and pinch off just enough
dough to mold with. Leave the rest in a plastic bag until needed.
Fill a small bowl with water to use as glue when you want to stick
pieces together. When you have made an item you want to keep
it on a floured cookie sheet and bake in the oven at 250 degrees fo
at least an hour."

Preheat oven to 475 degrees.
Discard gizzards form birds and trim necks flush with bodies if necessary.
Rinse birds inside and out and pat dry. Starting at neck end of each bird
slide fingers between meat and skin to loosen skin (be careful not to tear
skin). Cut butter into eight 1/4-inch thick slices and gently push 4 slices
under skin of each bird
column2: putting 1 slice over each breast half and thigh.

column1: Tie legs of each bird together with kitchen string and secure wings to
sides with wooden picks or bamboo skewers.

without crowding. Gently rub birds with lemon halves
them
column2: and season with salt and pepper. Roast birds in middle of oven 30

column1: minutes
column2: or until an instant read thermometer inserted in thickest part of

column1: a thigh registers 170 degrees.

wine and stock to the roasting pan and deglaze over moderate heat
up brown bits. Transfer jus to a small saucepan. Skim fat from jus and
simmer until reduced to about 1/3 cup.
Garnish birds with herbs and serve with jus.
Yield: 2 servings"

column1: Bread Recipe;6 c Flour;1 pk Dry yeast;1/2 c Milk;3 tb Sugar;2 ts Salt;;3 tb Butter or margarine;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Heat the milk 3 tbsp butter and 1.5 cups water to about 130 degrees. Add

column2: combine almond paste and sugar in mixing bowl. Using

column1: paddle attachment mix it until well blended and not lumpy. Add shortening

salt
column4: until well blended. Add flour slowly

column1: mixing on slow speed until blended.
For the crumb topping combine all ingredients in a medium bowl and combine

over bottom of ramekin
column2: spoon caramelized apples over first layer of

column1: batter. Spoon remaining cake batter over apples and sprinkle crunch topping

Bake in 350 degree oven for 25 to 30 minutes or until golden brown.
For the compote combine first five ingredients in saucepan and heat to a
slow simmer. Combine orange juice and cornstarch and add to blackberry
mixture. Continue to cook over low heat until slightly thickened. Remove
from heat.
To make the creme fraiche combine both ingredients in a small bowl. Whip
until smooth.
Unmold the buckles upside-down onto serving plate. Top with compote and
creme fraiche."

Chinese Almond Cookies;2 1/2 c All-purpose flour;3/4 c Sugar;1/4 ts Salt;1 ts Baking powder;3/4 c Margarine;;1 lg Egg;3 tb Water;1 ts Almond extract;36  Blanched almonds;1  Egg yolks;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"1. Place in large bowl the flour sifted with sugar
Use a pastry blender to cut in margarine (or butter) until mixture
resembles coarse cornmeal.
2. Beat egg with 2 tablespoons water and almond extract. Add to flour
mixture and mix with fork until dough leaves side of bowl.
3. Knead dough on a lightly floured surface until smooth. Wrap in waxed
paper and refrigerate for 1 hour.
4. Form dough into balls 1-inch in diameter and place 3 inches apart on
ungreased cookie sheets. Using palm of hand
thick. Keep dough in a circle shape.  Press whole almond in center of
cookie.
5. Combine egg yolk with 1 tablespoon water. Brush onto each cookie.
6. Bake in preheated 350-degree oven for 20 to 25 minutes
brown. Remove to wire racks to cool.  Yield: about 36 cookies."

fingers; slice into 3"" strips.

Earth Oven Roast Pig;ROAST PIG;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"The night before have some strong men dig pit 10-15 in"" deep Find small
(1to2) lb lava (porous) rock and some hard wood. Eucalyptis
wood and rock to make huge mound in the pit and set on fire about 3AM.
Coals and white hot rocks will be ready about 7. check each hour.
Salt/Pepper pig inside and out; rub hard. pig should be room temperature.
Cover rock/embers with wet banana leaves - 3 to 6 layers. Possible to use
seaweed
column2: corn stalk leaves.  Cover this with layers of wet burlap sacks.

column1: start at outside and layer like shingles on a roof to the middle. Put pit
on a small section of small wire fence section like you keep chicks in.
With tongs put several hot rocks in pig cavity near thickest part of meat.
Spread one layer banana leaves on burlap and place pig in the middle of the
pit. (encased in the wire). Banana leaves over the pig and then cover with
burlap again starting from outside and like roof shingles to the middle.
Shovel the dirt back in the pit completely covering. Don't leave any holes.
Sprinkle lightly with garden hose. Steam will escape but keep well covered.
About 4 or 5 in the afternoon it will be done. Also fun to put in a few
chickens/whole fish/goats all wrapped tightly in foil. Very carefully
shovel dirt from top of pit. When the middle burlap is seen start rolling
it back toward the sides and ends. Pig will be thoroughly cooked with meat
falling off bone. Put on picnic table and let the guests pick their own
pieces. Serve with Hawaiian POI and sea salt. Treat POI like bread never
eating it alone but with hunks of pork."

This is a very special Greek pastry."

This unique terracotta baking dish will enable you to roast garlic bulbs to

column2: the extra large size allow you to also roast giant ""Elephant

column1: Garlic"" and onions. Be sure to read the instructions carefully for best

column2: brushes or steel wool. NOT DISHWASHER SAVE. TO

column1: OVEN ROAST GARLIC: 1. Soak terracotta dome in cold water for 15 minutes.
(This step is optinal
column2: but will make the garlic more moist. The garlic bulb

column1: will roast without soaking the dome.) 2. Cut top 1/2"" to 3/4"" off of a bulb
of garlic exposing the clove tops. (If using Elephant Garlic
about an inch or more.) 3. Remove some of the loose outer skin (but not
all) leaving the bulb intact. 4. Place garlic onto plate and pour
approximately 1 tablespoon of olive oil on top of the bulb (optional). 5.
Cover with dome and starting in a cold oven
325 degrees. 6. Serve the roasted garlic whole. Squeeze each clove and
spread soft garlic onto hot crusty french bread rounds or crispy crackers.
FOR MICROWAVE: Prepare garlic bulb and soak dome as directed above and cook
for 5 to 6 minutes on medium or 2 to 3 minutes on high. You may have to
cook the garlic for up to 50 seconds more
your microwave. Great for use in dips and dishes.
TO OVEN ROAST AN ONION: Wash a medium sized onion
and bake at 350 degrees for approximately 1-1/2 hours until tender. Slice
off the root end (abut 1/4"") and squeeze soft onion out from skin. Great
topping for seafood
sandwiches etc.

spinkle with 1/4 teaspoon of dried herbs for an extra zesty flavor. Roasted

pasta!

Glorious Garlic Soup;"1 md Onion; sliced";"10  Cloves garlic; finely chopped";4 tb Butter;1 ts Vegetable oil (up to);2 tb Fresh parsely (chopped);;Salt and pepper to taste;4 c Water;4  Bouillon cubes;4 sl Italian or French bread (optional);4 sl Swiss cheese;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"A friend sent this recipe to me after I sent him the ""Additional effects""

1. Saute onion and garlic in butter and oil until the onion is soft.  Do

2. Pour in 4 cups water and bring to boil.  Add bouillon cubes and simmer
covered with a lid
Optional:  Broil bread on both sides until crisp.  Turn off broiler

serving of soup. Serve immediately.
Note:  This recipe is very potent.  Consuming two or more servings at a
single seating has been known to levitate bedsheets.  Couples should limit
their per person servings.  Smoking in bed is definitely not recommended."

the angelica take up as much sugar as will stick to it. Then dry off the

possible temperature.  I place the stalks directly on the oven shelves

How To Melt Chocolate;No ingredients;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"TIPS FOR SUCCESSFUL MELTING:
Follow directions carefully.
Do not overheat; these products scorch easily.
Microwave directions have been tested with microwave ovens ranging from 500
to 700 watts (output). Times given are to be considered guidelines;
microwave ovens differ in timing and heating patterns.
Stirring frequently is important whether using rangetop directions or
microwave directions. In the microwave oven
keep their shape and may not appear melted after heating
fluid after stirring.
Handle glass microwave dishes with a hot pad after melting; the container
may be hotter than the contents.
Wash and dry the melting utensil thoroughly after each use. Any residue
will affect the taste of the chocolate.
Do not allow chocolate to come in contact with moisture during melting
since this can cause lumping
one or two tablespoons shortening
chocolate; stir until fluid.
Do not use butter or margarine since these may contain water. Do not use
oil since this may prevent the mixture from setting up which is especially
important if it is being used for a glaze.
Break baking chocolate or candy bars into pieces to speed the melting
process."

Kecap Manis.  And even if it's not you might find some use for it...
Put all the ingredients in a large pot and cook on medium till onions
are limp.  Add sugar and bring to a boil to dissolve sugar.  Strain

but you will probably find that you can use it for things and not
worry about a ""salty"" taste."

Jalapeno Poppers #2 Pt 1;"175 Whole jalapeno chile pepper; stems removed";8 oz Cream cheese;"8 oz Cheddar cheese; ex. sharp
column2: finely shredded";"8 oz Monterey jack cheese; finely shredded";1/2 cn Beer;;"Vegetable batter; (generic pre mixed)";"Garlic salt; to taste";"Onion salt; to taste";"Black pepper; to taste";"Cayenne; to taste";"White cornmeal; for coating";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"There are essentially 5 functional parts of the perfect popper:

column1: 1. The pepper 2. The filling 3. The initial batter 4. The breading 5. The
final batter
The peppers: Fresh jalapenos.
A potato peeler with a pointed end is the perfect tool for deseeding. The
radius of the peeler allows you to make a hole about 1 cm in diameter
which is optimized for efficient seed removal
popper
column2: and minimal leakage (more on that later). Stab the pepper adjacent

column1: to the stem
column2: with the stem on the concave side of your peeler

column1: pepper roughly 1 radian and repeat. After 3 or 4 stabs
seperated the stem from the rest of the pepper. Pull out
twisting motion
column2: and you will remove most of the seeds. A little additional

column1: scraping may be required to get out the innards. Put aside and repeat until
done.
The filling: Mix equal weights of cream cheese
(sharp or v.sharp)
column2: and finely shredded Monterey jack. My batch used 8

column1: ounces of each. Mix these together in a bowl
no change in consistency.
The batters: Both of them have basically the same ingredients. The
differences are in consistency (and time of preparation). Don't use milk
for the batter. It won't grab the pepper
Beer works best of beer
column3: & milk. Use generic fried vegetable batter

column1: (I used the Chuck Wagon stuff)
column2: and an equal part of flour. Season with

column1: garlic salt
in the batter and in the unsuspecting faces of your guests). I used about 1
teaspoon of each to about 1/2 cup each of chuck wagon stuff and flour.
For the initial batter
batter. This is to hold the breading to the popper. If you add too much
beer at the start
column2: add flour to thicken. I think it took about half a beer

column1: for this.
For the final batter
column3: it should take less than a

column1: second for the batter to 'climb' the tines of a fork when removed and held
vertically over the batter. This has an added bonus of making those little
crunchy things to eat with the poppers. This was still less than a whole
beer
column2: so don't get too carried away- make it thick and add the beer in

column1: small amts. Remember
column2: don't make this until you're serving them!

column1: The breading: Just a plate with a pile of white cornmeal
The process: After coring a sink full of peppers
the cheese. Use your pinkie to pack the cheese in good
inch divot on the end of the pepper (recessed cheese
clear). Then line up your thick batter and corn meal
lined with aluminum foil. Dip the pepper in the batter
cheese and tip ends. Allow as much of the excess batter as you can stand to
drip off. Then place the pepper in the corn meal. Pick up a handful of meal
and bury the pepper. Place your hand on top of the pile (cupped)
some light pressure to help everything pack together. Pick up the pepper
and shake off the excess meal. Again
column2: handle the pepper by the tips

column1: helps minimize the bald spots. Place the pepper on the tray
million (OK
column3: but it seems like a million) times. Place the pan in the

column1: freezer. This is called flash freezing. After about half an hour (the time
it takes to fill the next tray) remove the first tray
poppers in a big ziplock bag. Put the bag back in the freezer. Wait
overnight or longer.
The serving of and eating of poppers: Heat up grease in your fry daddy.
Make the final (thin) batter. Get some of your frozen poppers. Some of the
breading may have come off in spots
column2: don't sweat it. Dip the popper in the

column1: thin batter and put in the grease. Cook until golden brown. Conveniently
this is also the point where the cheese is melted
overcooked. Pop in yer mouth.
Possible variations: A friend suggested that the initial batter/breading
might have nothing to do with the success of the final batter sticking
that the freezing may be the trick there. If true
column2: It would save a lot of

column1: work! I haven't had a chance to try it yet. Please tell me how these turn
out when you try them!

Historical note:  The reason why they're called ""johnny cakes"" is that when
the pioneers were going West across the Plains
column2: they had to cook over an

column1: open camp fire at night
column2: and eat left-overs for breakfast and lunch. So

column1: the pioneer women would make a thick corn dough
flat bottom side of a hoe
column2: and prop the hoe next to the fire so that the

column1: cakes could cook (they didn't have griddles-natch!). These cakes would be
used on the trail next day for lunch (stashed in your pocket so you could
eat it on horseback)
corrupted into ""johnny cakes""."

Key Lime Pie 7;1  9 inch graham cracker pie shell;"1 1/2 ts Lime rind; grated";"1/2 c Fresh lime juice; from about 3 limes";"1/4 c Fresh lemon juice; from about 1 lemon";"28 oz Sweetened condensed milk; 2 (14oz) cans";;1/4 ts Green food coloring;"Sweetened whipped cream; for garnish";"1 1/4 c Graham crackers; finely crushed";"2 tb Margarine; melted";2 ts Sugar;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"GRAHAM CRACKER PIE SHELL

column2: wash limes well. Using a hand-held grater

food coloring together gently with spoon; avoid over mixing. Pour into

GRAHAM CRACKER PIE SHELL: Combine all ingredients and mix well. Place in

minutes.

combination of lime juice with the lemon juice is very close to the actual

well.) Use a hand grater
peel. Just avoid the white pith underneath
column2: as its taste is quite bitter."

Cheesecakes are about as close as you can get to the ultimate dessert
this one is no exception. If you've never made a cheesecake before
be delighted at how simple it is. Best of all-because you need to make the
cheesecake ahead of time so that it has time to cool and set-it keeps you
from last-minute hassles.

Molded Cranberry Relish #3;700 g Marshmallow creme;250 ml Heavy whipping cream;100 g Cream cheese;300 g Fresh cranberries;200 ml Water;;180 g Raspberry Jello mix (1 package);50 g Granulated sugar;300 g Tokay grapes (quartered and seeded);"300 g Celery; chopped fine";"500 g Canned crushed pineapple; including syrup (one";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Dressing: 1. The night before serving the relish
and marshmallow creme in a small bowl. Mash lightly with a fork to barely

overnight.
3.  15 minutes before  serving
column2: whip mixture with an electric mixer until

column1: it reaches the consistency of thick
Relish:
1.  Rinse cranberries thoroughly.  Place in .AB ""an 8-cup"" ""a 2-liter
saucepan with water
column2: and cover.  Bring to a boil and cook until the berries

column1: have ``popped.''
2.  Remove from heat and
the berries are broken.
3.  Add Jello and sugar.  Plan saucepan over a bowl of ice and stir
occasionally until mixture has thickened but not jelled.
4.  Add grapes
5.  Pour into prepared mold and chill in refrigerator until set (about 3
hours).
6.  To serve
column2: unmold relish onto a plate and place dressing in a separate

column1: dish. Serve a couple of dollops of dressing with each serving of relish.
Author's Notes:
For years my mother required us to taste her ever-changing version of a
fresh cranberry relish she insisted serving at Thanksgiving and Christmas.
The unanimous family response to the inevitably bitter dish was
have to?''  Then one year a friend came to Thanksgiving dinner and
contributed what is now known simply as ``the recipe.''  Mom never tried to
improve on this addictive relish.
The most difficult step is in unmolding the relish.  I always spray my
mold very lightly with a coating of an aerosol cooking oil (such as
``PAM'') before filling it with the relish.  When it's time to unmold
run a thin spatula around the outside of the molded relish to barely loosen
it
column2: place the serving plate on top and invert the mold and plate. I rarely

column1: have to dip the mold in hot water to loosen the relish. I usually use a
standard ring mold and put the dressing in a footed compote which sits in
the center of the unmolded ring of relish.
Difficulty    : moderate. Precision
: approximate measurement OK."

Pad Thai (Stir Fried Noodles);8 oz Rice vermicelli (up to);"6  Cloves garlic; finely chopped";2 tb Chopped shallots;"1/4 c Dried shrimp (rolled; or roughly pounded in a mortar and pestle to break them up)";1/4 c Fish sauce;;1/4 c Palm sugar (up to);3 tb Tamarind juice (up to);"3 tb Chopped; pickled radish (mooli)";"1 md Egg; beaten";1/4 c Chopped chives;"1/2 c Roasted peanuts; very coarsely broken up";1 c Bean sprouts;1/2 c Fried tofu marinated in dark sweet soy or an equivalent amount of coarsely chopped pork or chicken;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Pad Thai is often called the signature dish of Thai cuisine.  There are
several regional variations
column2: indeed it has been said that Thailand has a

column1: different curry for every day of the year
column2: but a different pad thai for

column1: every cook in Thailand! This is my wife's variation.
This variation uses a small amount of khao koor (powdered fried rice)
which occurs as an ingredient in several other Thai recipes. You can make a
small amount and keep it almost indefinitely in a jar with a tight lid.
You also need a cup of dry roasted
column2: unsalted peanuts.  We roast them in

column1: their shells on a charcoal brazier
column2: but you can do it just as well in an

column1: oven
column2: or even in a skillet. However
column3: they should be freshly roasted to

column1: bring out the full flavor for this dish.
NOTE: rice vermicelli (either the sen mee or the sen lek style of Thai
noodles or indeed any rice noodles will do).  These should be soaked for a
short while (perhaps 30 minutes to an hour
noodles) until soft.
Method: Heat a little cooking oil in a wok and add the garlic and shallots
and briefly stir fry until they just shows signs of changing color.  Add
the remaining ingredients except the egg and the bean sprouts
until the protein ingredient is nearly cooked. Continuing to stir with one
hand
column2: slowly ""drizzle"" in the beaten egg to form a fine ribbon of cooked

column1: egg (if you don't feel confident with this make an egg crepe separately
and then roll it up and slice it into quarter inch wide pieces
add to the mix at this point). Finely add the bean sprouts and cook for no
more than another 30 seconds. Remove from the pan to a serving platter.
Garnish: Mix a tablespoon of lime juice with a tablespoon of tamarind juice
and a tablespoon of fish sauce
column2: and use this to marinade half a cup of

column1: uncooked bean sprouts
column2: half a cup of chopped chives
column3: and half a cup of very

column1: coarsely ground roasted peanuts.  Sprinkle this mixture on the cooked pad
thai.  Cut several limes into segments and also slice up some cucumber into
rounds then halve the rounds.  Put the lime segments and cuke segments
around the serving platter.
You can also sprinkle a quarter of a sliced up banana flower and some
Indian pennywort leaves over the top as edible decoration.
Pad thai is served as above
column2: but Thais add copious amounts of the four

column1: basic condiments (chilis in fish sauce
crushed peanuts) at the table

Note on Fennel:  It's sometimes marketed as anise.  The bulb is the best
part.  Standard procrdure for fennel is to whack off the stalks
the bulb lengthwise and cut out the base like you would for cabbage. At
that point it's ready for slicing or dicing.
Having said the bulb is the best part
column2: I should say that there's nothing

column1: wrong with the stalks.  in fact
column2: if you were stuck with a small bulb

column1: can dice a stalk and use it in this recipe.  The major difference is that
the stalks are more fibrous
good to eat raw instead of celery (provided you like licorice)."

Pennsylvania Dutch Shoofly Pie;1  Batch flaky pie dough for a 1-crust pie;3/4 c Water;"1/2 c Molasses; (not unsulphured)";1/2 c Dark corn syrup;3/4 ts Baking soda mixed with 1 tablespoon water;;1 1/4 c All purpose bleached flour;1/2 c Light brown sugar;8 tb Unsalted butter;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"FILLING
Prepare and chill the dough.
For the filling
column2: bring the water to a boil in a 3-quart saucepan and remove

column1: from heat. Stir in molasses and corn syrup. Stir in baking soda/water
mixture (the mixture will foam up in the pan). Set aside to cool. Combine
flour and sugar in a mixing bowl and rub in butter until the mixture forms
1/4 to 1/2-inch crumbs. Set aside.
Preheat oven to 400 degrees and set a rack in the lowest level. For the
bottom crust
column2: lightly flour the work surface and the dough and roll it to a

column1: 12-inch disk. Fold the dough in half and place it in the pan; unfold the
dough and press it firmly into the pan. Trim away all but 1/2-inch excess
dough at the edge of the pan. Fold excess dough under and flute edge.
Pour cooled molasses mixture into crust and evenly scatter the crumbs over
it.
Bake the pie for 15 minutes on the bottom rack of the oven. Lower the
temperature to 350 degrees and move the pie to the middle rack. (Place a
jelly roll pan lined with aluminum foil on the rack below and under the pie
to catch drips if the filling begins to boil over). Bake the pie about 20
to 30 minutes longer
column2: until the crust and crumb topping are a deep golden."

Pesach Hazelnut-Chocolate Viennese Torte);6 lg Eggs -- 5 of them separated;pn Salt;2 ts Lemon juice;3/4 c Sugar -- divided;2 ts Lemon rind -- grated;;3 oz Semisweet Chocolate -- very finely grated;2 1/2 c Unblanched nuts -- very finely ground;For Torte:;1/4 c Sweet Pesach wine;1/2 c Apricot jam;Chocolate Glaze:;1/3 c Water;3 tb Vegetable oil;1 c Sugar;1/2 c Cocoa;Garnish: (optional);1 c Nuts -- ground;12  Hazelnuts;1 oz Chocolate -- for curls;;;;;;;;"Grease a 9 inch springform pan well and coat it with potato starch or

light and fluffy.  Gently but thouroughly fold the beaten whites into
yolks.  Fold in chocolate and nuts
Bake torte in a preheated 325 degree oven for 50-55 minutes or until top
springs back when gently pressed.
[this will not rise as much as you think it ought. Don't worry about it]
Leave the torte in the oven
After 10 minutes remove torte from oven. Run a knife around the edge of the
torte to release it from the pan rim.  Cool it for another 30 minutes in
the pan. Remove the pan rim and cool the torte completely on the bottom.
[This next part is for icing the Torte.  What I've done in the past is make
2 layers
syrup and dribbled half over each torte as per the directions and skipped

freezer paper or use a cake plate. Invert torte onto base and remove pan
bottom. Sprinkle wine [or whatever] evenly over torte. Heat jam until
thinned; then bruch or spread it all over the torte. (this adds flavor and
smooths the surface).

column5: and cocoa in a small suacepan

Press handfulls of ground nuts all over the sides
whole nuts

Refrigerate the uncovered

MAKING THE DOUGH: Combine salt and flour and heap this mixture in a bowl.

column2: when poked with the index finger

column1: both sides have been cooked once

heat

column1: little

Note: The cut of meat specified above includes the rib bones to which the

boned

column3: and by cooking it along with the

column1: bones
column2: the roast benefits from the substantial contribution of flavor the

column1: bones make.
Another cut of pork that is well suited to this dish is the boneless roll
of muscle at the base of the neck
column2: sometimes known as Boston butt. There is

column1: a layer of fat in the center of the butt that runs the length of the
muscle. It makes this cut very juicy and tasty
later

column1: you don't think this would be a problem

column1: butt because of its excellent flavor and juiciness. Should you do so

column2: basting the meat and keeping it from drying. When the

Prehistoric Potato Fish;10  Green beans;"1 md Potato; scrubbed";2  Green olive;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Cook green beans in lightly salted boiling water until crisp-tender

microwave-safe paper towel in the microwave oven. Microwave 5 to 6 minutes
until softened and cooked through.
Peel potato when cool enough to handle. Cut in half lengthwise. Place each
potato half on a plate. Make 5 horizontal cuts 1/2"" apart. Lay one potato
slice flat on plate. range 4 green beans between standing potato slices.
Cut one green bean in half to form tail. Make an eye using a thick slice of
green olive; form a mouth with a piece of pimento."

column1: to 60 minutes.

column1: approximately 45 minutes before the meat is done. Mix the glaze ingredients

column2: and bring them to a simmer

column1: mixture for 30 minutes.

60 minutes of cooking time. (Never apply glaze before the last hour or it
will burn.) Return the remaining glaze to the stove
it's reduced by one-third
After removing the ribs from the pit
then trim the fat. Serve them with the reduced glaze on the side."

Pumpkin Rolls Abm;1 c Milk;"1 tb Butter; or margarine";1/4 c Sugar;1/2 ts Salt;"1/2 ts Cinnamon; up to 1";;1/2 c Oats;2 1/2 c Bread flour;1 1/2 ts Fast acting yeast;1 c Canned pumpkin;"1/2 c Raisins; (or dried cranberries)";1/2 c Brown sugar;"1/2 c Chopped pecans; or walnuts";;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"DOUGH
FILLING
These rolls are a decadent treat which just happen to be very low in fat so
you can really enjoy them.
Remove dough upon completion of cycle and roll into a rectangle on a
floured counter. Add only enough flour to prevent sticking. Mix all filling
ingredients together and spread evenly over dough.
Roll dough in a jelly-roll fashion wide end to wide end. Cut into 12 equal
pieces and place in greased muffin tins. Cover and let rise in a warm
draft free location for 30-45 minutes.
Bake in a preheated 350 F. over for 20-30 min. or until golden brown."

Santa Cruz Natto (Fermented Soybeans);2 c Dried soybeans;Water;1 pk Commercial natto;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"**Note: Please read the entire recipe first and make a note of the
ingredients and utensils that will be needed. The starter culture must be
obtained from store-bought natto
column2: unless you have other sources such as

column1: rice straw.**
1. Soak two cups of dried soybeans overnight in ten cups of water.
2. Put the soybeans in a stainless steel basket (or colander) and cover it
with a piece of cloth slightly larger than the basket.
3. Put the above in a pressure cooker with 3 cups water
the stove. Turn on the stove.
4. After the pressure cooker starts hissing
column2: turn down the flame so that

column1: the hissing is at its minimum level.
5. Cook for 15 minutes (measured from the time the hissing has started).
6. DO NOT OPEN the pressure cooker yet. Allow the pressure cooker and its
contents to cool down. If waiting is not your style
cooker in the sink filled with cold water. (The soy beans are considered to
have cooled down as long as its temperature is below 140 degrees F.)
7. Make sure that the kitchen counter and its surrounding area are
absolutely clean. Sterilize a tablespoon with boiling water.
8. Wash your hands and arms - long-sleeved shirts not recommended.
9. Have a package of commercial natto ready.
10. Open the lid of the pressure cooker
column2: peel back the cloth cover to one

column1: end of the basket
spoonfuls of natto starter with the beans. Replace the cloth cover.
11. Close the pressure cooker lid with its air relief hole _uncovered_.
12. Place the cooker in a picnic ice-chest and place an electric heating
pad over it. Replace the ice-chest cover.
The natto will be ready in between 24 and 48 hours
temperature of the heating pad. As an alternate heat source
lightbulb may be used. If you don't have a pressure cooker
may be used. In this case
column2: the cooking time will need to be increased to

column1: about two hours
column2: and the amount of cooking water to about six cups."

*Baked roux: Lots of Louisiana recipes start with ""First you make a roux. ""
The traditional roux is a mixture of about equal parts of oil and flour
browned to a certain point. A baked roux can substitute nicely in some
recipes. To bake a roux
column2: preheat oven to 400 degrees. Put some (about 1/3

column1: c.) of flour pie pan or cake pan which has been sprayed with PAM. Bake at
400 degrees stirring frequently until roux is caramel colored and just
begins to have a burnt smell. Don't bake it any longer! Store roux in
refrigerator . When recipe calls for roux add an equal measure of water to
whatever amount of flour is called for in the recipe."

The Story:
The rural origins of Appenzell cookery are evident even in this substantial
honey cake. It is very fashionable during the festivities at the end of the
year to serve a spiced honey cake following the example of the famous
triangular ""Biberli""
column2: which also blends honey and spices. This recipe is

column1: inspired by the ""Bacheschnitte"" which are served on the ""Funkensonntag""
spring festival held to exorcise all the evil spirits of winter by fire.
The recipe:
Gently heat the honey in a copper bowl or a bain-marie.
Heat the milk with the sugar separately then add to the honey and stir well
over a low heat. Leave to cool.
Put the flour into another bowl and stir in the honey mixture and then the
other ingredients.
Work all these together to a smooth consistency .
Place a greased flan ring (22 ... 24 cm diameter
tray and fill with the mixture.
Brush the top with milk and score a decorative pattern on the surface using
a fork.
Bake in the oven for 30 minutes at 180 oC (test with a needle).

Strawberry Trifle Recipe;1 1/2 tb Cornstarch;1/2 c Half & half;1 3/4 c Whole milk;3 tb Granulated sugar;1 ts Vanilla;;"3  Egg yolks; beaten";1  10-oz pound or sponge cake;1/3 c Strawberry jam;3 tb Cream sherry;3 c Strawberries;1 c Whipping cream;2 tb Powdered sugar;1 ts Vanilla;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"DESSERT
Prepare the custard first: Mix the cornstarch with the half & half. Heat
the milk with the sugar just to boiling in a heavy saucepan. Remove from
the heat. Stir in the cornstarch mixture. Return to heat. Cook
until the mixture thickens. Simmer 2 or 3 minutes. Remove from the heat.
Add the vanilla and the egg yolks. Whisk until almost cold. Cover. Chill.
Prepare the trifle: Cut the cake into even slices. Spread each with jam and
reassemble the cake. Cut into 2"" cubes. Arrange the cubes in individual
bowls. Sprinkle with cream sherry. Wash and slice the strawberries. Set a
few strawberries aside for garnish. Divide the strawberries among the
individual bowls. Pour the custard over the strawberries and cake in the
bowls. Drizzle with a little strawberry jam. Cover each bowl. Chill. Whip
the cream until soft peaks form. Add the sugar and vanilla. Garnish each
trifle with some sliced strawberries. Top with whipped cream. Chill
briefly.  Serve."

Strawberry-Alomond Cream Napoleons with Strawberry Sauce;"1  Sheet; (half a 17-oz package) puff pastry";1 pk (4-serving size) instant vanilla pudding mix;1 c Skim Milk;1 ts Almond Extract;1 c Light frozen whipped topping;;"2 pt Strawberries; stemmed";"2 tb Granulated Sugar; up to 3";1 ts Fresh lemon juice;"1/3 c Sliced almonds; toasted";Powdered sugar for garnish;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Heat oven to 400 degrees. Thaw folded pastry sheet 20 minutes. Open sheet
and cut along folds to make 3 equal strips; halve each strip to make 6
rectangles. Space each apart on baking sheet. Bake in the center of the

to cool. Meanwhile
fold in whipped topping to blend throughly. Cover and refridgerate. Slice
enough strawberries to make 2 cups; set aside. To make strawberry sauce;
halve the remaining strawberries and puree in blender with granulated sugar
and lemon juice until smooth; set aside. Carefully split each piece of
pastry in half horizontally. Cover bottom halves with almonds
mixture and sliced berries
column2: dividing equally. Cover with pastry tops. Dust

column1: with powdered sugar. Serve with strawberry sauce. Note: All components of
this recipe can be prepared several hours in advance. Cover and

column2: sauce and strawberries. Assemble just before

column1: serving."

1. Preheat oven to 450. On a lightly floured surface
Dough into a 9-inch round; do not roll any larger. Fold in half and

Texas Barbecued Beef Brisket;10 lb Beef brisket;"2 c All-south barbecue rub; see";2 c Basic all-american bbq sauce;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"1. Rub the brisket
thoroughly on all its sides with the barbecue rub
column2: and allow it to come to

on one side as far up against one wall as possible. Place the brisket on

grab the cooler. This is where a person learns about the Zen of Barbecue.
You gotta keep the fire going
column2: but very quietly. If you've got a

column1: thermometer on your covered grill
column2: you want to keep the temperature between

column1: 180 and 220 F. Remer
column2: ""Slow and low is the way to go."" You have to figure

coals or wood chunks to every beer.  This goes on for about 8 to 10 hours
or however long you can make it

column1: the darkening of the exterior
column2: the outside of the brisket will be

column1: superdark--my personal favorite part. 3. Upon completion
out
column3: and slice it thin. Serve with barbecue sauce

column1: on the side--no pro would ever cover properly cooked brisket with sauce
he'd just dab on a touch. Obviously the key here is a tremendous amount of
patience and a day when you want to do nothing but sit around. But the end
product is one of those great culinary events that results from spending a

the barbecue process was invented. My research
that there was a strong German immigrant communitu in Texas around the turn
of the century. It has some of these Germans working in the booming Texas
cattle industry
column2: and others working in butcher shops

column1: strong background in butchering and charcuterie. It being common knowledge
that butchers are constantly trying to turn tough or inexpensive cuts of
meat into a usable product that brings a higher cost (witness sausages and
pates)
column2: it has these German butchers faced with the brisket. This cut of

column1: beef is particularly unwanted because of the huge percentage of fat that
runs ont only on the surface
column2: but throughout the cut. Traditional technique

column1: would braise or pickle this cut to tenderize it
column2: but the brisket also has a

column1: lot of beef flavor. In my personal opinion
column2: a vey smart German butcher who

column1: ws looking for a way to market this cut barbecued it. We're not talking
here about the that was already popular in this area
cooking
column2: in which the cooking is done by convection ratherr than

column1: conduction. It is similar to braising in theory
the water. It is cooked at very low heat for a long period of time
high fat content protects the meat from drying out but also disappears
through the 10 - 18 hour cooking process. What you are left with is very
tender meat with little or no fat and a tremendous smoky beef flavor. I
think the meat and the process were literally invented for each other.
Now
column2: I don't think that you will get any disagreement from the professional

column1: barbecue industry when I say that brisket is the hardest to master--but
hey
column2: learning is half the fun. And
column3: in the words of Remus Powers

brisket

Tony's Poppers;Cheddar cheese;Jalapeno chiles;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"Slice some Cheddar brick cheese into logs that will fit into a cored out
Jalapeno. Place them on a plate in the freezer for later.
Take a fresh Jalapeno and slice it almost in half the long way so the
halves are still attached at the stem end. Hold the halves open like an
alligator's mouth and with a potato peeler core out the seeds and membrane.
Be careful not to let the halves split apart.
Mix up the batter.   I use graham flour and water.  Mix to the consistency
thin or thick depending on how much breading you like on the pepper. You
can add any spices you like to the batter. We use none.
Preheat the deep fryer to 400 degrees. The hotter the oil the browner the
skin.
Pull the cheese from the freezer and insert a frozen piece into the pepper.
Run a toothpick on an angle through the 2 halves on the open ends to keep
the whole thing together. Drop the pepper in the batter and get it coated
good
Drop the pepper in the oil and leave it in there until the cheese starts
dancing out of the pepper
column2: or until you think it is just about to.

column1: Drain on paper towels and use cocktail sauce for dipping
remove toothpick before dipping.
Chase with a good shot of Tequila."

*** Cake ***

Very Berry Summer Pudding;"2 pt (12-oz each) strawberries; rinsed and hulled";"1 c Blueberries; rinsed and picked over";1/2 c Granulated sugar;1/4 c Orange juice;1/4 c Plus;;2 tb Seedless red raspberry or strawberry jam;1/2 ts Ground cinnamon;"1 c Blackberries; cut in half if large";"16 sl Thin; firm sandwich-style bread; crusts trimmed";1 ts Lemon juice;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;"This no-bake bread pudding is traditionally made with fresh red currants
and raspberries
column2: but you can use any combination of juicy berries as we've

column1: done here.
1.  Line a 1-1/2 quart souffle dish or mixing bowl with plastic wrap
leaving a 4-inch overhang all around.
2.  Finely mash 1-1/2 cups of the strawberries and 1/4 cup blueberries in a
large bowl. Slice in remaining strawberries and stir in remaining
blueberries and the sugar. Let stand 15 minutes
3.  Mix orange juice
column2: 1/4 cup jam and the cinnamon. Add the strawberry

column1: mixture along with the blackberries. Stir until blended.
4.  Line bottom of prepared dish with 3 slices bread
fit snugly. Cut 8 of the remaining slices in half. Arrange halves
overlapping slightly
to keep it in place.
5.  Spoon half the berry mixture and juice into dish. Press down to
compact. Top with 2 slices bread
column2: then the remaining berries and juice.

column1: Press down. Cover completely with remaining 3 bread slices
6.  Bring up plastic wrap overhang and cover top of dish completely. Top
with a plate that fits inside dish (or cut cardboard to fit). Place in
refrigerator and put a heavy weight (large juice or tomato can or brick) on
plate to press layers down firmly.
7.  Refrigerate at least 8 hours
column2: but preferably overnight so juices soak

column1: the bread.
8.  TO SERVE: Remove weight and unwrap top of pudding. Invert on rimmed
serving dish to catch juices. Remove dish and plastic wrap. Stir lemon
juice into remaining 2 tablespoons jam. Brush evenly over pudding. Use a
serrated knife to cut into wedges. Makes 8 servings.
REQUIRES CHILLING"
